Social Projects To
Get Dorm Students
Started On Plan
An active social program and a
good example by upper-classmen
was emphasized by DSRC president
Dave Jennings as the main points
of a policy to get the dormitory
residents off to a good start this
year.
"We are trying to instill the idea
that each dormitory. student is
expected to have his actions guided
.by consideration for the men he
is living with," Jennings said.
Tentatively planned are tea
dances after some of the football
games and several evening dances
with girls from Goucher. Transportation has been arranged to
bring the girls from Goucher in a
group to the football games.
Cooperation Needed
Jim Phinney, class of '55, has
been appointed social director of
the dormitory. "My main problem
right now is to. work up a budget.
Until then plans are very tentative," he said. He has set up a
joint Hopkins-Goucher committee

and new responsibilities.
Around him he sees his future environment—the stately
Georgian buildings in which he will live and work, the grounds
about which he will wander in search of a moment's peace, and,
most ituportant, the men from whom he will pick lifetime friends.
Even if he is fortunate enough to be making the jump from high
school to college in the company of a friend, he is subject to
a few moments of intense loneliness at the thought of what he
has left behind. Anticipation of the future, now unknown and
fearful, will come later.
Soon, however, some trivial incident breaks the barriers with
which he has surrounded himself. Perhaps he may open his dormitory door to be greeted with an onrush of water from a:malfunctioning water system; he will find it very difficult to be unfriendly
while 'being part of a sleepy, pajama-clad team that is sweeping
Water from the corridor at one o'clock in the morning.
From the beginning of Orientation, the green Hopkins man
associates himself more and more with the University. He is
made to feel at home at once, for at the Hopkins there are no
degrading customs of initiation which for want of good sense are
termed"good fun." Those to whom he is introduced are introduced
more as friends than as superiors; he is even given a chance to
subject a panel of his future professors to an inquisition.
Each day the new man is shown, through informal talks and
lectures on activities, study methods, and the all-important Honor
System, the responsibilities he has assumed. He becomes more and
more impressed as he realizes the traditions he will be called upon
to uphold, and within a week's time, he feels settled, his confidence returns, and he is-prepared to begin work., That condition of
mind alone must stand as a tribute to the supporters and originators of the Orientation Program for a good job WO done.
The daily spectacle of men_ who have dedicated their lives
to the search for the truth is an example for the new Hopkins man
to follow: The Hopkins is not merely an institution where knowledge is passed from one to another; it is a community devoted to
training men ready to accept the challenge of life—and able to
Meet it.

associates himself more and more with the University. He is
made to feel at home at once, for at the Hopkins there are no
degrading customs of initiation which for want of good sense are
